H0.text: Swims faster is the reason an iguana that lives in the water on the Galapagos Islands is most likely able to survive without competition from an iguana that lives on land.

H1.text: Has a larger body is the reason why a water‑dwelling iguana on the Galapagos Islands can survive without competition from a land‑dwelling iguana.

H2.text: Has a tougher scaly skin, allowing the water‑dwelling iguana on the Galapagos Islands to survive without competition from a land‑dwelling iguana.

H3.text: The iguana that lives in the water on the Galapagos Islands is most likely able to survive without competition from an iguana that lives on land because it has a different food source.

A4.text: Unique among modern lizards, it is a marine reptile that has the ability to forage in the sea for algae, which make up almost all of its diet.

A5.text: The hindgut of marine iguanas is specially adapted to algae feeding, likely restricting the possibility of efficiently switching to other plant types.
